Chapter 3 Pursuing Low-Dimensional Distributions via Lossy Compression

In this chapter
  • Entropy Minimization and Compression
    Entropy and Coding RateDifferential EntropyMinimizing Coding Rate
  • Compression via Denoising
    Diffusion and Denoising ProcessesLearning and Sampling a Distribution via Iterative Denoising
  • Compression via Lossy Coding
    Necessity of Lossy CodingRate Distortion and Data GeometryLossy Coding Rate for a Low-Dimensional GaussianClustering a Mixture of Low-Dimensional Gaussians
  • Maximizing Information Gain
    Linear Discriminative RepresentationsThe Principle of Maximal Coding Rate ReductionOptimization Properties of Coding Rate Reduction
  • Summary and Notes
  • Exercises and Extensions

â€œWe compress to learn, and we learn to compress.â€
â€„ â€” High-dimensional Data Analysis, Wright and Ma, 2022

In Chapter 2, we have shown how to learn simple classes of distributions whose supports are assumed to be either a single or a mixture of low-dimensional subspaces or low-rank Gaussians. For further simplicity, the different (hidden) linear or Gaussian modes are assumed to be orthogonal or independent111Or can be easily reduced to such idealistic cases., as illustrated in Figure 2.4. As we have shown, for such special distributions, one can derive rather simple and effective learning algorithms with correctness and efficiency guarantees. The geometric and statistical interpretation of operations in the associated algorithms is also very clear.

In practice, both linearity and independence are rather idealistic assumptions that distributions of real-world high-dimensional data rarely satisfy. The only thing that we may assume is that the intrinsic dimension of the distribution is very low compared to the dimension of the ambient space in which the data are embedded. Hence, in this chapter, we show how to learn a more general class of low-dimensional distributions in a high-dimensional space that is not necessarily (piecewise) linear.

It is typical that the distribution of real data often contains multiple components or modes, say corresponding to different classes of objects in the case of images. These modes might not be statistically independent and they may even have different intrinsic dimensions. It is also typical that we have access to only a finite number of samples of the distribution. Therefore, in general, we may assume our data are distributed on a mixture of (nonlinear) low-dimensional submanifolds in a high-dimensional space. Figure 3.1 illustrates an example of such a distribution.

To learn such a distribution under such conditions, there are several fundamental questions that we need to address:

  • â€¢

    What is a general approach to learn a general low-dimensional distribution in a high-dimensional space and represent the learned distribution?

  • â€¢

    How do we measure the complexity of the resulting representation so that we can effectively exploit the low dimensionality to learn?

  • â€¢

    How do we make the learning process computationally tractable and even scalable, as the ambient dimension is usually high and the number of samples typically large?

As we will see, the fundamental idea of compression, or dimension reduction, which has been shown to be very effective for the linear/independent case, still serves as a general principle for developing effective computational models and methods for learning general low-dimensional distributions.

Due to its theoretical and practical significance, we will study in greater depth how this general framework of learning low-dimensional distributions via compression substantiates when the distribution of interest can be well-modeled or approximated by a mixture of low-dimensional subspaces or low-rank Gaussians.

3.1 Entropy Minimization and Compression

3.1.1 Entropy and Coding Rate

In Chapter 1, we have mentioned that the goal of learning is to find the simplest way to generate a given set of data. Conceptually, the Kolmogorov complexity was intended to provide such a measure of complexity but it is not computable and not associated with any implementable scheme that can actually reproduce the data. Hence we need an alternative, computable, and realizable, measure of complexity. That leads us to the notion of entropy, introduced by Shannon in 1948 [Sha48].

To illustrate the constructive nature of entropy, let us start with the simplest case. Suppose that we have a discrete random variable that takes NNitalic_N distinct values, or tokens, {ğ’™1,â€¦,ğ’™N}\{\bm{x}_{1},\ldots,\bm{x}_{N}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with equal probability 1/N1/N1 / italic_N. Then we could encode each token ğ’™i\bm{x}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the log2â¡N\log_{2}Nroman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N-bit binary representation of iiitalic_i. This coding scheme could be generalized to encoding arbitrary discrete distributions [CT91]: Given a distribution ppitalic_p such that âˆ‘i=1Npâ€‹(ğ’™i)=1\sum_{i=1}^{N}p(\bm{x}_{i})=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1, one could assign each token ğ’™i\bm{x}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability pâ€‹(ğ’™i)p(\bm{x}_{i})italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to a binary code of size log2â¡[1/pâ€‹(ğ’™i)]=âˆ’log2â¡pâ€‹(ğ’™i)\log_{2}[1/p(\bm{x}_{i})]=-\log_{2}p(\bm{x}_{i})roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 1 / italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = - roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bits. Hence the average number of bits, or the coding rate, needed to encode any sample from the distribution pâ€‹(â‹…)p(\cdot)italic_p ( â‹… ) is given by the expression:222By the convention of Information Theory [CT91], the log\logroman_log here is to the base 222. Hence entropy is measured in (binary) bits.

Hâ€‹(ğ’™)â‰ğ”¼â€‹[logâ¡1/pâ€‹(ğ’™)]=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1Npâ€‹(ğ’™i)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(ğ’™i).H(\bm{x})\doteq\mathbb{E}[\log 1/p(\bm{x})]=-\sum_{i=1}^{N}p(\bm{x}_{i})\log p(\bm{x}_{i}).italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) â‰ blackboard_E [ roman_log 1 / italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) ] = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.1.1)

This is known as the entropy of the (discrete) distribution pâ€‹(â‹…)p(\cdot)italic_p ( â‹… ). Note that this entropy is always nonnegative and it is zero if and only if pâ€‹(ğ’™i)=1p(\bm{x}_{i})=1italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 for some ğ’™i\bm{x}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with iâˆˆ[N]i\in[N]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_N ].333Here notice that we use the fact limpâ†’0pâ€‹logâ¡p=0\lim_{p\rightarrow 0}p\log p=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p â†’ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p roman_log italic_p = 0.

3.1.2 Differential Entropy

When the random variable ğ’™âˆˆâ„D\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}bold_italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is continuous and has a probability density ppitalic_p, one may view that the limit of the above sum (3.1.1) is related to an integral:

hâ€‹(ğ’™)â‰ğ”¼â¡[logâ¡1/pâ€‹(ğ’™)]=âˆ’âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ.h(\bm{x})\doteq\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\log 1/p(\bm{x})]=-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log p(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}.italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) â‰ blackboard_E [ roman_log 1 / italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) ] = - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ . (3.1.2)

More precisely, given a continuous variable ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x, we may quantize it with a quantization size Ïµ>0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0. Denote the resulting discrete variable as ğ’™Ïµ\bm{x}^{\epsilon}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then one can show that Hâ€‹(ğ’™Ïµ)+logâ¡(Ïµ)â‰ˆhâ€‹(ğ’™)H(\bm{x}^{\epsilon})+\log(\epsilon)\approx h(\bm{x})italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + roman_log ( italic_Ïµ ) â‰ˆ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ). Hence, when Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ is small, the differential entropy hâ€‹(ğ’™)h(\bm{x})italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) can be negative. Interested readers may refer to [CT91] for a more detailed explanation.

Example 3.1 (Entropy of Gaussian Distributions).

Through direct calculation, it is possible to show that the entropy of a Gaussian distribution xâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î¼,Ïƒ2)x\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma^{2})italic_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( italic_Î¼ , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is given by:

hâ€‹(x)=12â€‹logâ¡(2â€‹Ï€â€‹Ïƒ2)+12.h(x)=\frac{1}{2}\log(2\pi\sigma^{2})+\frac{1}{2}.italic_h ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_log ( 2 italic_Ï€ italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG . (3.1.3)

It is also known that the Gaussian distribution achieves the maximal entropy for all distributions with the same variance Ïƒ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The entropy of a multivariate Gaussian distribution ğ’™âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğ,ğšº)\bm{x}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma})bold_italic_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ , bold_Î£ ) in â„D\mathbb{R}^{D}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is given by:

hâ€‹(ğ’™)=D2â€‹(1+logâ¡(2â€‹Ï€))+12â€‹logâ€‹det(ğšº).h(\bm{x})=\frac{D}{2}(1+\log(2\pi))+\frac{1}{2}\log\det(\bm{\Sigma}).italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG italic_D end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + roman_log ( 2 italic_Ï€ ) ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_log roman_det ( bold_Î£ ) . (3.1.4)

â– \blacksquareâ– 

Similar to the entropy for a discrete distribution, we would like the differential entropy to be associated with the coding rate of some realizable coding scheme. For example, as above, we may discretize the domain of the distribution with a grid of size Ïµ>0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0. The coding rate of the resulting discrete distribution can be viewed as an approximation to the differential entropy [CT91].

Be aware that there are some caveats associated with the definition of differential entropy. For a distribution in a high-dimensional space, when its support becomes degenerate (low-dimensional), its differential entropy diverges to âˆ’âˆ-\infty- âˆ. This fact is proved in TheoremÂ B.1 (we also recall the maximum entropy characterization of the Gaussian distribution mentioned above in TheoremÂ B.1) but even in the simple explicit case of Gaussian distributions (3.1.4), when the covariance ğšº\bm{\Sigma}bold_Î£ is singular, we can see that logâ€‹det(ğšº)=âˆ’âˆ\log\det(\bm{\Sigma})=-\inftyroman_log roman_det ( bold_Î£ ) = - âˆ so we have hâ€‹(ğ’™)=âˆ’âˆh(\bm{x})=-\inftyitalic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = - âˆ. In such a situation, it is not obvious how to properly quantize or encode such a distribution. Nevertheless, degenerate (Gaussian) distributions are precisely the simplest possible, and arguably the most important, instances of low-dimensional distributions in a high-dimensional space. In this chapter, we will discuss a complete resolution to this seeming difficulty with degeneracy.

3.1.3 Minimizing Coding Rate

Remember that the learning problem entails the recovery of a (potentially continuous) distribution pâ€‹(ğ’™)p(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) from a set of samples {ğ’™1,â€¦,ğ’™N}\{\bm{x}_{1},\ldots,\bm{x}_{N}\}{ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } drawn from the distribution. For ease of exposition, we write ğ‘¿=[ğ’™1,â€¦,ğ’™N]âˆˆâ„DÃ—N\bm{X}=[\bm{x}_{1},\ldots,\bm{x}_{N}]\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times N}bold_italic_X = [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D Ã— italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Given that the distributions of interest here are (nearly) low-dimensional, we should expect that their (differential) entropy is very small. But unlike the situations that we have studied in the previous chapter, in general we do not know the family of (analytical) low-dimensional models to which the distribution pâ€‹(ğ’™)p(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) belongs. So checking whether the entropy is small seems to be the only guideline that we can rely on to identify and model the distribution.

Now given the samples alone without knowing what pâ€‹(ğ’™)p(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) is, in theory they could be interpreted as samples from any generic distribution. In particular, they could be interpreted as any of the following cases:

  1. 1.

    as samples from the empirical distribution pğ‘¿p^{\bm{X}}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT itself, which assigns 1/N1/N1 / italic_N probability each of the NNitalic_N samples ğ’™i,i=1,â€¦,N\bm{x}_{i},i=1,\ldots,Nbold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i = 1 , â€¦ , italic_N.

  2. 2.

    as samples from a standard normal distribution ğ’™nâˆ¼pnâ‰ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,Ïƒ2â€‹ğ‘°)\bm{x}^{n}\sim p^{n}\doteq\mathcal{N}(\bm{0},\sigma^{2}\bm{I})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) with a variance Ïƒ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT large enough (say larger than the sample norms);

  3. 3.

    as samples from a normal distribution ğ’™eâˆ¼peâ‰ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,ğšº^)\bm{x}^{e}\sim p^{e}\doteq\mathcal{N}(\bm{0},\hat{\bm{\Sigma}})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , over^ start_ARG bold_Î£ end_ARG ) with a covariance ğšº^=1Nâ€‹ğ‘¿â€‹ğ‘¿T\hat{\bm{\Sigma}}=\frac{1}{N}\bm{X}\bm{X}^{T}over^ start_ARG bold_Î£ end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG bold_italic_X bold_italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT being the empirical covariance of the samples;

  4. 4.

    as samples from a distribution ğ’™^âˆ¼q^â€‹(ğ’™)\hat{\bm{x}}\sim\hat{q}(\bm{x})over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG âˆ¼ over^ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG ( bold_italic_x ) that closely approximates the ground truth distribution ppitalic_p.

Now the question is which one is better, in what sense? Suppose that you believe these data ğ‘¿\bm{X}bold_italic_X are drawn from a particular distribution qâ€‹(ğ’™)q(\bm{x})italic_q ( bold_italic_x ), which may be one of the above distributions considered. Then we could encode the data points with the optimal code book for the distribution qâ€‹(ğ’™)q(\bm{x})italic_q ( bold_italic_x ). The required average coding length (or coding rate) is given by:

1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ’logâ¡qâ€‹(ğ’™i)â‰ˆâˆ’âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡qâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}-\log q(\bm{x}_{i})\quad\approx\quad-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log q(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ (3.1.5)

as the number of samples NNitalic_N becomes large. If we have identified the correct distribution pâ€‹(ğ’™)p(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ), the coding rate is given by the entropy âˆ’âˆ«pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ-\int p(\bm{\xi})\log p(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}- âˆ« italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾. It turns out that the above coding length âˆ’âˆ«pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡qâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ-\int p(\bm{\xi})\log q(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}- âˆ« italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ is always larger than or equal to the entropy unless qâ€‹(ğ’™)=pâ€‹(ğ’™)q(\bm{x})=p(\bm{x})italic_q ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_p ( bold_italic_x ). Their difference, denoted as

ğ–ªğ–«â¡(pâˆ¥q)\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathsf{KL}}(p\;\|\;q)sansserif_KL ( italic_p âˆ¥ italic_q ) â‰\displaystyle\doteqâ‰ âˆ’âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡qâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒâˆ’(âˆ’âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ)\displaystyle-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log q(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}-\Big{(}-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log p(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}\Big{)}- âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ - ( - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ ) (3.1.6)
=\displaystyle== âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(ğƒ)qâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dâ€‹ğƒ\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log\frac{p(\bm{\xi})}{q(\bm{\xi})}\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ (3.1.7)

is known as the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, or relative entropy. This quantity is always non-negative.

Theorem 3.1 (Information Inequality).

Let pâ€‹(ğ±),qâ€‹(ğ±)p(\bm{x}),q(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) , italic_q ( bold_italic_x ) be two probability density functions (that have the same support). Then ğ–ªğ–«â¡(pâˆ¥q)â‰¥0\operatorname{\mathsf{KL}}(p\;\|\;q)\geq 0sansserif_KL ( italic_p âˆ¥ italic_q ) â‰¥ 0, where the inequality becomes equality if and only if p=qp=qitalic_p = italic_q.444Technically, this equality should be taken to mean â€œalmost everywhereâ€, i.e., except possibly on a set of zero measure (volume), since this set would not impact the value of any integral.

Proof.
âˆ’ğ–ªğ–«â¡(pâˆ¥q)\displaystyle-\operatorname{\mathsf{KL}}(p\;\|\;q)- sansserif_KL ( italic_p âˆ¥ italic_q ) =\displaystyle== âˆ’âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(ğƒ)qâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dâ€‹ğƒ=âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹logâ¡qâ€‹(ğƒ)pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dâ€‹ğƒ\displaystyle-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log\frac{p(\bm{\xi})}{q(\bm{\xi})}\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\log\frac{q(\bm{\xi})}{p(\bm{\xi})}\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}- âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_log divide start_ARG italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG roman_d bold_italic_Î¾
â‰¤\displaystyle\leqâ‰¤ logâ€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹qâ€‹(ğƒ)pâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ=logâ€‹âˆ«â„Dqâ€‹(ğƒ)â€‹dğƒ=logâ¡1=0,\displaystyle\log\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{\xi})\frac{q(\bm{\xi})}{p(\bm{\xi})}\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}=\log\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}q(\bm{\xi})\mathrm{d}\bm{\xi}=\log 1=0,roman_log âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) divide start_ARG italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) end_ARG roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ = roman_log âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ) roman_d bold_italic_Î¾ = roman_log 1 = 0 ,

where the first inequality follows from Jensenâ€™s inequality and the fact that the function logâ¡(â‹…)\log(\cdot)roman_log ( â‹… ) is strictly concave. The equality holds if and only if p=qp=qitalic_p = italic_q . âˆ

Hence, given a set of sampled data ğ‘¿\bm{X}bold_italic_X, to determine which case is better among pnp^{n}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, pep^{e}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and q^\hat{q}over^ start_ARG italic_q end_ARG, we may compare their coding rates for ğ‘¿\bm{X}bold_italic_X and see which one gives the lowest rate. We know from the above that the (theoretically achievable) coding rate for a distribution is closely related to its entropy. In general, we have:

hâ€‹(ğ’™n)>hâ€‹(ğ’™e)>hâ€‹(ğ’™^).h(\bm{x}^{n})>h(\bm{x}^{e})>h(\hat{\bm{x}}).italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > italic_h ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ) . (3.1.8)

Hence, if the data ğ‘¿\bm{X}bold_italic_X were encoded by the code book associated with each of these distributions, the coding rate for ğ‘¿\bm{X}bold_italic_X would in general decrease in the same order:

pâ€‹(ğ’™n)â†’pâ€‹(ğ’™e)â†’pâ€‹(ğ’™^).p(\bm{x}^{n})\rightarrow p(\bm{x}^{e})\rightarrow p(\hat{\bm{x}}).italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â†’ italic_p ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â†’ italic_p ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ) . (3.1.9)

This observation gives us a general guideline on how we may be able to pursue a distribution pâ€‹(ğ’™)p(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) which has a low-dimensional structure. It suggests two possible approaches:

  1. 1.

    Starting with a general distribution (say a normal distribution) with high entropy, gradually transforming the distribution towards the (empirical) distribution of the data by reducing entropy.

  2. 2.

    Among a large family of (parametric or non-parametric) distributions with explicit coding schemes that encode the given data, progressively search for better coding schemes that give lower coding rates.

Conceptually, both approaches are essentially trying to do the same thing. For the first approach, we need to make sure such a path of transformation exists and is computable. For the second approach, it is necessary that the chosen family is rich enough and can closely approximate (or contain) the ground truth distribution. For either approach, we need to ensure that solutions with lower entropy or better coding rates can be efficiently computed and converge to the desired distribution quickly.555Say the distribution of real-world data such as images and texts. We will explore both approaches in the two remaining sections of this chapter.

3.2 Compression via Denoising

In this section, we will describe a natural and computationally tractable way to learn a distribution pâ€‹(ğ’™)p(\bm{x})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) by way of learning a parametric encoding of our distribution such that the representation has the minimum entropy or coding rate, then using this encoding to transform high-entropy samples from a standard Gaussian into low-entropy samples from the target distribution, as illustrated in FigureÂ 3.2. This presents a methodology that utilizes both approaches above in order to learn and sample from the distribution.

3.2.1 Diffusion and Denoising Processes

We first want to find a procedure to decrease the entropy of a given very noisy sample into a lower-entropy sample from the data distribution. Here, we describe a potential approachâ€”one of many, but perhaps the most natural way to attack this problem. First, we find a way to gradually increase the entropy of existing samples from the data distribution. Then, we find an approximate inverse of this process. But in general, the operation of increasing entropy does not have an inverse, as information from the original distribution may be destroyed. We will thus tackle a special case where (1) the operation of adding entropy takes on a simple, computable, and reversible form; (2) we can obtain a (parametric) encoding of the data distribution, as alluded to in the above pair of approaches. As we will see, the above two factors will ensure that our approach is possible.

We will increase the entropy in arguably the simplest possible way, i.e., adding isotropic Gaussian noise. More precisely, given the random variable ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x, we can consider the stochastic process (ğ’™t)tâˆˆ[0,T](\bm{x}_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which adds gradual noise to it, i.e.,

ğ’™tâ‰ğ’™+tâ€‹ğ’ˆ,âˆ€tâˆˆ[0,T],\bm{x}_{t}\doteq\bm{x}+t\bm{g},\qquad\forall t\in[0,T],bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ bold_italic_x + italic_t bold_italic_g , âˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] , (3.2.1)

where Tâˆˆ[0,âˆ]T\in[0,\infty]italic_T âˆˆ [ 0 , âˆ ] is a time horizon and ğ’ˆâˆ¼ğ’©â¡(ğŸ,ğ‘°)\bm{g}\sim\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\bm{I})bold_italic_g âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , bold_italic_I ) is drawn independently of ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x. This process is an example of a diffusion process, so-named because it spreads out the probability mass out over all of â„D\mathbb{R}^{D}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as time goes on, increasing the entropy over time. This intuition is confirmed graphically by FigureÂ 3.3, and rigorously via the following theorem.

Theorem 3.2 (Simplified Version of TheoremÂ B.2).

Suppose that (ğ±t)tâˆˆ[0,T](\bm{x}_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows the model (3.2.1). For any tâˆˆ(0,T]t\in(0,T]italic_t âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_T ], the random variable ğ±t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has differential entropy hâ€‹(ğ±t)>âˆ’âˆh(\bm{x}_{t})>-\inftyitalic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > - âˆ. Moreover, under certain technical conditions on ğ±\bm{x}bold_italic_x,

ddâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹(ğ’™t)>0,âˆ€tâˆˆ(0,T],\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}h(\bm{x}_{t})>0,\qquad\forall t\in(0,T],divide start_ARG roman_d end_ARG start_ARG roman_d italic_t end_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 0 , âˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_T ] , (3.2.2)

showing that the entropy of the noised ğ±\bm{x}bold_italic_x increases over time ttitalic_t.

The proof is elementary, but it is rather long, so we postpone it to SectionÂ B.2.1. The main as-yet unstated implication of this result is that hâ€‹(ğ’™t)>hâ€‹(ğ’™)h(\bm{x}_{t})>h(\bm{x})italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) for every t>0t>0italic_t > 0. To see this, note that if hâ€‹(ğ’™)=âˆ’âˆh(\bm{x})=-\inftyitalic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = - âˆ then hâ€‹(ğ’™t)>âˆ’âˆh(\bm{x}_{t})>-\inftyitalic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > - âˆ for all t>0t>0italic_t > 0, and if hâ€‹(ğ’™)>âˆ’âˆh(\bm{x})>-\inftyitalic_h ( bold_italic_x ) > - âˆ then hâ€‹(ğ’™t)=hâ€‹(ğ’™)+âˆ«0t[ddâ€‹sâ€‹hâ€‹(ğ’™s)]â€‹ds>hâ€‹(ğ’™)h(\bm{x}_{t})=h(\bm{x})+\int_{0}^{t}[\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}s}h(\bm{x}_{s})]\mathrm{d}s>h(\bm{x})italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG roman_d end_ARG start_ARG roman_d italic_s end_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] roman_d italic_s > italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) by the fundamental theorem of calculus, so in both cases hâ€‹(ğ’™t)>hâ€‹(ğ’™)h(\bm{x}_{t})>h(\bm{x})italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) for every t>0t>0italic_t > 0.

The inverse operation to adding noise is known as denoising. It is a classical and well-studied topic in signal processing and system theory, such as the Wiener filter and the Kalman filter. The several problems discussed in ChapterÂ 2, such as PCA, ICA, and Dictionary Learning, are specific instances of the denoising problem. For a fixed ttitalic_t and the additive Gaussian noise model (3.2.1), the denoising problem can be formulated as attempting to learn a function ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , â‹… ) which forms the best possible approximation (in expectation) of the true random variable ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x, given both ttitalic_t and ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,â‹…)âˆˆargâ€‹minğ’™Â¯â€‹(t,â‹…)â¡ğ”¼ğ’™,ğ’™tâ¡â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™Â¯â€‹(t,ğ’™t)â€–22.\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\cdot)\in\operatorname*{arg\ min}_{\bar{\bm{x}}(t,\cdot)}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}_{\bm{x},\bm{x}_{t}}\|\bm{x}-\bar{\bm{x}}(t,\bm{x}_{t})\|_{2}^{2}.overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , â‹… ) âˆˆ start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t , â‹… ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3.2.3)

The solution to this problem, when optimizing ğ’™Â¯â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t , â‹… ) over all possible (square-integrable) functions, is the so-called Bayes optimal denoiser:

ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,ğƒ)â‰ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t=ğƒ].\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\bm{\xi})\doteq\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t}=\bm{\xi}].overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_italic_Î¾ ) â‰ blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Î¾ ] . (3.2.4)

This expression justifies the notation ğ’™Â¯\bar{\bm{x}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG, which is meant to compute a conditional expectation (i.e., conditional mean or conditional average). In short, it attempts to remove the noise from the noisy input, outputting the best possible guess (in expectation and w.r.t.Â the â„“2\ell^{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-distance) of the (de-noised) original random variable.

Example 3.2 (Denoising Gaussian Noise from a Mixture of Gaussians).

In this example we compute the Bayes optimal denoiser for an incredibly important class of distributions, the Gaussian mixture model. To start, let us fix parameters for the distribution: mixture weights ğ…âˆˆâ„K\bm{\pi}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}bold_italic_Ï€ âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, component means {ğk}k=1KâŠ†â„D\{\bm{\mu}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{D}{ bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ† blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and component covariances {ğšºk}k=1KâŠ†ğ–¯ğ–²ğ–£â€‹(D)\{\bm{\Sigma}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}\subseteq\mathsf{PSD}(D){ bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ† sansserif_PSD ( italic_D ), where ğ–¯ğ–²ğ–£â€‹(D)\mathsf{PSD}(D)sansserif_PSD ( italic_D ) is the set of DÃ—DD\times Ditalic_D Ã— italic_D symmetric positive semidefinite matrices. Now, suppose ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x is generated by the following two-step procedure:

  • â€¢

    First, an index (or label) yâˆˆ[K]y\in[K]italic_y âˆˆ [ italic_K ] is sampled such that y=ky=kitalic_y = italic_k with probability Ï€k\pi_{k}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • â€¢

    Second, ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x is sampled from the normal distribution ğ’©â¡(ğy,ğšºy)\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{\mu}_{y},\bm{\Sigma}_{y})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Then ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x has distribution

ğ’™âˆ¼âˆ‘k=1KÏ€kâ€‹ğ’©â¡(ğk,ğšºk),\bm{x}\sim\sum_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{k}\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{\mu}_{k},\bm{\Sigma}_{k}),bold_italic_x âˆ¼ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (3.2.5)

and so

ğ’™t=ğ’™+tâ€‹ğ’ˆâˆ¼âˆ‘k=1KÏ€kâ€‹ğ’©â¡(ğk,ğšºk+t2â€‹ğ‘°).\bm{x}_{t}=\bm{x}+t\bm{g}\sim\sum_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{k}\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{\mu}_{k},\bm{\Sigma}_{k}+t^{2}\bm{I}).bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x + italic_t bold_italic_g âˆ¼ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) . (3.2.6)

Let us define Ï†â€‹(ğ’™;ğ,ğšº)\varphi(\bm{x};\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma})italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_Î¼ , bold_Î£ ) as the probability density of ğ’©â¡(ğ,ğšº)\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ , bold_Î£ ) evaluated at ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x. In this notation, the density of ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is

ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)=âˆ‘k=1KÏ€kâ€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğk,ğšºk+t2â€‹ğ‘°).p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{k}\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{\mu}_{k},\bm{\Sigma}_{k}+t^{2}\bm{I}).italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) . (3.2.7)

Conditioned on yyitalic_y, the variables are jointly Gaussian: if we say that ğ’™=ğy+ğšºy1/2â€‹ğ’–\bm{x}=\bm{\mu}_{y}+\bm{\Sigma}_{y}^{1/2}\bm{u}bold_italic_x = bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_u where (â‹…)1/2(\cdot)^{1/2}( â‹… ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the matrix square root and ğ’–âˆ¼ğ’©â¡(ğŸ,ğ‘°)\bm{u}\sim\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{0},\bm{I})bold_italic_u âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_0 , bold_italic_I ) independently of yyitalic_y (and ğ’ˆ\bm{g}bold_italic_g), then we have

[ğ’™ğ’™t]=[ğyğy]+[ğšºy1/2ğŸğšºy1/2tâ€‹ğ‘°]â€‹[ğ’–ğ’ˆ].\begin{bmatrix}\bm{x}\\ \bm{x}_{t}\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\bm{\mu}_{y}\\ \bm{\mu}_{y}\end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}\bm{\Sigma}_{y}^{1/2}&\bm{0}\\ \bm{\Sigma}_{y}^{1/2}&t\bm{I}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}\bm{u}\\ \bm{g}\end{bmatrix}.[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL bold_0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_t bold_italic_I end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_u end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_g end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] . (3.2.8)

This shows that ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x and ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are jointly Gaussian (conditioned on yyitalic_y) as claimed. Thus we can write

[ğ’™ğ’™t]âˆ¼ğ’©â¡([ğyğy],[ğšºyğšºyğšºyğšºy+t2â€‹ğ‘°]).\begin{bmatrix}\bm{x}\\ \bm{x}_{t}\end{bmatrix}\sim\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\left(\begin{bmatrix}\bm{\mu}_{y}\\ \bm{\mu}_{y}\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}\bm{\Sigma}_{y}&\bm{\Sigma}_{y}\\ \bm{\Sigma}_{y}&\bm{\Sigma}_{y}+t^{2}\bm{I}\end{bmatrix}\right).[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] , [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ) . (3.2.9)

Thus the conditional expectation of ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x given ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., the Bayes optimal denoiser conditioned on yyitalic_y) is famously (ExerciseÂ 3.2)

ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t,y]=ğy+ğšºyâ€‹(ğšºy+t2â€‹ğ‘°)âˆ’1â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ’ğy).\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t},y]=\bm{\mu}_{y}+\bm{\Sigma}_{y}(\bm{\Sigma}_{y}+t^{2}\bm{I})^{-1}(\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu}_{y}).blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ] = bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.2.10)

To find the overall Bayes optimal denoiser, we use the law of iterated expectation, obtaining

ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,ğ’™t)\displaystyle\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\bm{x}_{t})overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t]\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t}]= blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (3.2.11)
=ğ”¼â¡[ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t,y]âˆ£ğ’™t]\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t},y]\mid\bm{x}_{t}]= blackboard_E [ blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y ] âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (3.2.12)
=âˆ‘k=1Kâ„™â¡[y=kâˆ£ğ’™t]â€‹ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t,y=k].\displaystyle=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}[y=k\mid\bm{x}_{t}]\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t},y=k].= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P [ italic_y = italic_k âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y = italic_k ] . (3.2.13)

The probability can be dealt with as follows. Let ptâˆ£yp_{t\mid y}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the probability density of ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT conditioned on the value of yyitalic_y. Then

â„™â¡[y=kâˆ£ğ’™t]\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}[y=k\mid\bm{x}_{t}]blackboard_P [ italic_y = italic_k âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] =ptâˆ£yâ€‹(ğ’™tâˆ£k)â€‹Ï€kptâ€‹(ğ’™t)\displaystyle=\frac{p_{t\mid y}(\bm{x}_{t}\mid k)\pi_{k}}{p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}= divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_k ) italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG (3.2.14)
=Ï€kâ€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğk,ğšºk+t2â€‹ğ‘°)âˆ‘i=1KÏ€iâ€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ği,ğšºi+t2â€‹ğ‘°).\displaystyle=\frac{\pi_{k}\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{\mu}_{k},\bm{\Sigma}_{k}+t^{2}\bm{I})}{\sum_{i=1}^{K}\pi_{i}\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{\mu}_{i},\bm{\Sigma}_{i}+t^{2}\bm{I})}.= divide start_ARG italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) end_ARG . (3.2.15)

On the other hand, the conditional expectation is as described before:

ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t,y=k]=ğk+ğšºkâ€‹(ğšºk+t2â€‹ğ‘°)âˆ’1â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ’ğk).\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t},y=k]=\bm{\mu}_{k}+\bm{\Sigma}_{k}(\bm{\Sigma}_{k}+t^{2}\bm{I})^{-1}(\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu}_{k}).blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y = italic_k ] = bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.2.16)

So putting this all together, the true Bayes optimal denoiser is

ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,ğ’™t)=âˆ‘k=1KÏ€kâ€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğk,ğšºk+t2â€‹ğ‘°)âˆ‘i=1KÏ€iâ€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ği,ğšºi+t2â€‹ğ‘°)â‹…(ğk+ğšºkâ€‹(ğšºk+t2â€‹ğ‘°)âˆ’1â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ’ğk)).\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\bm{x}_{t})=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\pi_{k}\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{\mu}_{k},\bm{\Sigma}_{k}+t^{2}\bm{I})}{\sum_{i=1}^{K}\pi_{i}\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{\mu}_{i},\bm{\Sigma}_{i}+t^{2}\bm{I})}\cdot\left(\bm{\mu}_{k}+\bm{\Sigma}_{k}(\bm{\Sigma}_{k}+t^{2}\bm{I})^{-1}(\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu}_{k})\right).overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) end_ARG â‹… ( bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) . (3.2.17)

This example is particularly important, and several special cases will give us great conceptual insight later. For now, let us attempt to extract some geometric intuition from the functional form of the optimal denoiser (3.2.17).

To try to understand (3.2.17) intuitively, let us first set K=1K=1italic_K = 1 (i.e., one Gaussian) such that ğ’™âˆ¼ğ’©â¡(ğ,ğšº)\bm{x}\sim\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma})bold_italic_x âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ , bold_Î£ ). Let us then diagonalize ğšº=ğ‘½â€‹ğš²â€‹ğ‘½âŠ¤\bm{\Sigma}=\bm{V}\bm{\Lambda}\bm{V}^{\top}bold_Î£ = bold_italic_V bold_Î› bold_italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then the Bayes optimal denoiser is

ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,ğ’™t)=ğ+ğšºâ€‹(ğšº+t2â€‹ğ‘°)âˆ’1â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ’ğ)=ğ+ğ‘½â€‹[Î»1/(Î»1+t2)â‹±Î»D/(Î»D+t2)]â€‹ğ‘½âŠ¤â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ’ğ),\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\bm{x}_{t})=\bm{\mu}+\bm{\Sigma}(\bm{\Sigma}+t^{2}\bm{I})^{-1}(\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu})=\bm{\mu}+\bm{V}\begin{bmatrix}\lambda_{1}/(\lambda_{1}+t^{2})&&\\ &\ddots&\\ &&\lambda_{D}/(\lambda_{D}+t^{2})\end{bmatrix}\bm{V}^{\top}(\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu}),overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_italic_Î¼ + bold_Î£ ( bold_Î£ + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ ) = bold_italic_Î¼ + bold_italic_V [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL â‹± end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] bold_italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ ) , (3.2.18)

where Î»1,â€¦,Î»D\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{D}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the eigenvalues of ğšº\bm{\Sigma}bold_Î£. We can observe that this denoiser has three steps:

  • â€¢

    Translate the input ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by ğ\bm{\mu}bold_italic_Î¼.

  • â€¢

    Contract the (translated) input ğ’™tâˆ’ğ\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ in each eigenvector direction by a quantity Î»i/(Î»i+t2)\lambda_{i}/(\lambda_{i}+t^{2})italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). If the translated input is low-rank and some eigenvalues of ğšº\bm{\Sigma}bold_Î£ are zero, these directions get immediately contracted to 0 by the denoiser, ensuring that the output of the contraction is similarly low-rank.

  • â€¢

    Translate the output back by ğ\bm{\mu}bold_italic_Î¼.

It is easy to show that it contracts the current ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT towards the mean ğ\bm{\mu}bold_italic_Î¼:

â€–ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,ğ’™t)âˆ’ğâ€–2â‰¤â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğâ€–2.\|\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\bm{x}_{t})-\bm{\mu}\|_{2}\leq\|\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{\mu}\|_{2}.âˆ¥ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (3.2.19)

This is the geometric interpretation of the denoiser of a single Gaussian. The overall denoiser of the Gaussian mixture model (3.2.17) uses KKitalic_K such denoisers, weighting their output by the posterior probabilities â„™â¡[y=kâˆ£ğ’™t]\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}[y=k\mid\bm{x}_{t}]blackboard_P [ italic_y = italic_k âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. If the means of the Gaussians are well-separated, these posterior probabilities are very close to 0 or 111 near each mean or cluster. In this regime, the overall denoiser (3.2.17) has the same geometric interpretation as the above single Gaussian denoiser.

At first glance, such a contraction mapping (3.2.19) may appear similar to power iterations (see SectionÂ 2.1.2). However, the two are fundamentally different. Power iteration implements a contraction mapping towards a subspaceâ€”namely the subspace spanned by the first principal component. In contrast, the iterates in (3.2.19) converge to the mean ğ\bm{\mu}bold_italic_Î¼ of the underlying distribution, which is a single point. â– \blacksquareâ– 

Intuitively, and as we can see from ExampleÂ 3.2, the Bayes optimal denoiser ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , â‹… ) should move its input ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT towards the modes of the distribution of ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x. It turns out that, actually, we can quantify this by showing that the Bayes optimal denoiser takes a gradient ascent step on the (log-)density of ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which (recall) we denoted ptp_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. That is, following the denoiser means moving from the input iterate to a region of higher probability within this (perturbed) distribution. For small ttitalic_t, the perturbation is small so our initial intutition is therefore (almost) exactly right. The picture is visualized in FigureÂ 3.4 and rigorously formulated as Tweedieâ€™s formula [Rob56].

Theorem 3.3 (Tweedieâ€™s Formula).

Suppose that (ğ±t)tâˆˆ[0,T](\bm{x}_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT obeys (3.2.1). Let ptp_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the density of ğ±t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (as previously declared). Then

ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t]=ğ’™t+t2â€‹âˆ‡ğ’™tlogâ¡ptâ€‹(ğ’™t).\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t}]=\bm{x}_{t}+t^{2}\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}\log p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t}).blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.2.20)
Proof.

For the proof let us suppose that ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x has a density (even though the theorem is true without this assumption), and call this density ppitalic_p. Let p0âˆ£tp_{0\mid t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 âˆ£ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ptâˆ£0p_{t\mid 0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the conditional densities of ğ’™=ğ’™0\bm{x}=\bm{x}_{0}bold_italic_x = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’™t\bm{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x respectively. Let Ï†â€‹(ğ’™;ğ,ğšº)\varphi(\bm{x};\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma})italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x ; bold_italic_Î¼ , bold_Î£ ) be the density of ğ’©â¡(ğ,ğšº)\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}(\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ , bold_Î£ ) evaluated at ğ’™\bm{x}bold_italic_x, so that ptâˆ£0â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ£ğ’™)=Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)p_{t\mid 0}(\bm{x}_{t}\mid\bm{x})=\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x ) = italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ). Then a simple calculation gives

âˆ‡ğ’™tlogâ¡ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)\displaystyle\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}\log p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =âˆ‡ğ’™tptâ€‹(ğ’™t)ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)\displaystyle=\frac{\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}{p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}= divide start_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG (3.2.21)
=1ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ‡ğ’™tâ€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹ptâˆ£0â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ£ğ’™)â€‹dğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})p_{t\mid 0}(\bm{x}_{t}\mid\bm{x})\mathrm{d}\bm{x}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x ) roman_d bold_italic_x (3.2.22)
=1ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ‡ğ’™tâ€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)â€‹dğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})\mathrm{d}\bm{x}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) roman_d bold_italic_x (3.2.23)
=1ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹[âˆ‡ğ’™tÏ†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)]â€‹dğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})[\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})]\mathrm{d}\bm{x}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) [ âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) ] roman_d bold_italic_x (3.2.24)
=1ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)â€‹[âˆ’ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™t2]â€‹dğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})\left[-\frac{\bm{x}_{t}-\bm{x}}{t^{2}}\right]\mathrm{d}\bm{x}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) [ - divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] roman_d bold_italic_x (3.2.25)
=1t2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)â€‹[ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™t]â€‹dğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})[\bm{x}-\bm{x}_{t}]\mathrm{d}\bm{x}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) [ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] roman_d bold_italic_x (3.2.26)
=1t2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)â€‹ğ’™â€‹dğ’™âˆ’ğ’™tt2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹Ï†â€‹(ğ’™t;ğ’™,t2â€‹ğ‘°)â€‹dğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})\bm{x}\mathrm{d}\bm{x}-\frac{\bm{x}_{t}}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})\varphi(\bm{x}_{t};\bm{x},t^{2}\bm{I})\mathrm{d}\bm{x}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) bold_italic_x roman_d bold_italic_x - divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ï† ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; bold_italic_x , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_I ) roman_d bold_italic_x (3.2.27)
=1t2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€‹ptâˆ£0â€‹(ğ’™tâˆ£ğ’™)â€‹ğ’™â€‹dğ’™âˆ’ğ’™tt2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)\displaystyle=\frac{1}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p(\bm{x})p_{t\mid 0}(\bm{x}_{t}\mid\bm{x})\bm{x}\mathrm{d}\bm{x}-\frac{\bm{x}_{t}}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x ) bold_italic_x roman_d bold_italic_x - divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (3.2.28)
=1t2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹âˆ«â„Dptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹p0âˆ£tâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t)â€‹ğ’™â€‹dğ’™âˆ’ğ’™tt2â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)â€‹ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)\displaystyle=\frac{1}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})p_{0\mid t}(\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t})\bm{x}\mathrm{d}\bm{x}-\frac{\bm{x}_{t}}{t^{2}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})}p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 âˆ£ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_x roman_d bold_italic_x - divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (3.2.29)
=1t2â€‹âˆ«â„Dp0âˆ£tâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t)â€‹ğ’™â€‹dğ’™âˆ’ğ’™tt2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{t^{2}}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{D}}p_{0\mid t}(\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t})\bm{x}\mathrm{d}\bm{x}-\frac{\bm{x}_{t}}{t^{2}}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 âˆ£ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_x roman_d bold_italic_x - divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG (3.2.30)
=1t2â€‹ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t]âˆ’ğ’™tt2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{t^{2}}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t}]-\frac{\bm{x}_{t}}{t^{2}}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] - divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG (3.2.31)
=ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™t]âˆ’ğ’™tt2.\displaystyle=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t}]-\bm{x}_{t}}{t^{2}}.= divide start_ARG blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (3.2.32)

Simple rearranging of the above equality proves the theorem. âˆ

This result develops a connection between denoising and optimization: the Bayes-optimal denoiser takes a single step of gradient ascent on the perturbed data density ptp_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the step size adaptively becomes smaller (i.e., taking more precise steps) as the perturbation to the data distribution grows smaller. The quantity âˆ‡ğ’™tlogâ¡ptâ€‹(ğ’™t)\nabla_{\bm{x}_{t}}\log p_{t}(\bm{x}_{t})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is called the (HyvÃ¤rinen) score and frequently appears in discussions about denoising, etc.; it first appeared in a paper of Aapo HyvÃ¤rinen in the context of ICA [Hyv05].

Similar to how one step of gradient descent is almost never sufficient to minimize an objective in practice when initializing far from the optimum, the output of the Bayes-optimal denoiser ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , â‹… ) is almost never contained in a high-probability region of the data distribution when ttitalic_t is large, especially when the data have low-dimensional structures. We illustrate this point explicitly in the following example.

Example 3.3 (Denoising a Two-Point Mixture).

Let xxitalic_x be uniform on the two-point set {âˆ’1,+1}\{-1,+1\}{ - 1 , + 1 } and let (ğ’™t)tâˆˆ[0,T](\bm{x}_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follow (3.2.1). This is precisely a degenerate Gaussian mixture model with priors equal to 12\frac{1}{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, means {âˆ’1,+1}\{-1,+1\}{ - 1 , + 1 }, and covariances both equal to 0. For a fixed t>0t>0italic_t > 0 we can use the calculation of the Bayes-optimal denoiser in (3.2.17) to obtain (proof as exercise)

xÂ¯âˆ—â€‹(t,xt)=Ï†â€‹(xt;+1,t2)âˆ’Ï†â€‹(xt;âˆ’1,t2)Ï†â€‹(xt;1,t2)+Ï†â€‹(xt;âˆ’1,t2)=tanhâ¡(âˆ’xtt2).\bar{x}^{\ast}(t,x_{t})=\frac{\varphi(x_{t};+1,t^{2})-\varphi(x_{t};-1,t^{2})}{\varphi(x_{t};1,t^{2})+\varphi(x_{t};-1,t^{2})}=\tanh\left(-\frac{x_{t}}{t^{2}}\right).overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG italic_Ï† ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; + 1 , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_Ï† ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; - 1 , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï† ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; 1 , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_Ï† ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; - 1 , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG = roman_tanh ( - divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) . (3.2.33)

For ttitalic_t near 0, this quantity is near {âˆ’1,+1}\{-1,+1\}{ - 1 , + 1 } for almost all inputs xÂ¯âˆ—â€‹(t,xt)\bar{x}^{\ast}(t,x_{t})overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). However, for ttitalic_t large, this quantity is not necessarily even approximately in the original support of xxitalic_x, which, remember, is {âˆ’1,+1}\{-1,+1\}{ - 1 , + 1 }. In particular, for xtâ‰ˆ0x_{t}\approx 0italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ 0 it holds xÂ¯âˆ—â€‹(t,xt)â‰ˆ0\bar{x}^{\ast}(t,x_{t})\approx 0overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ 0 which lies completely in between the two possible points. Thus xÂ¯âˆ—\bar{x}^{\ast}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will not output â€œrealisticâ€ xxitalic_x. Or more mathematically, the distribution of xÂ¯â€‹(t,xt)\bar{x}(t,x_{t})overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is very different from the distribution of xxitalic_x. â– \blacksquareâ– 

Therefore, if we want to denoise the very noisy sample ğ’™T\bm{x}_{T}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (whereâ€”recallâ€”TTitalic_T is the maximum time), we cannot just use the denoiser once. Instead, we must use the denoiser many times, analogously to gradient descent with decaying step sizes, to converge to a stationary point ğ’™^\hat{\bm{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG. Namely, we shall use the denoiser to go from ğ’™T\bm{x}_{T}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ğ’™^Tâˆ’Î´\hat{\bm{x}}_{T-\delta}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_Î´ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which approximates ğ’™Tâˆ’Î´\bm{x}_{T-\delta}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_Î´ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then from ğ’™^Tâˆ’Î´\hat{\bm{x}}_{T-\delta}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_Î´ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ğ’™^Tâˆ’2â€‹Î´\hat{\bm{x}}_{T-2\delta}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - 2 italic_Î´ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, etc., etc., all the way from ğ’™^Î´\hat{\bm{x}}_{\delta}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î´ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ğ’™^=ğ’™^0\hat{\bm{x}}=\hat{\bm{x}}_{0}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Each time we take a denoising step, the action of the denoiser becomes more like a gradient step on the original (log-)density.

More formally, we uniformly discretize [0,T][0,T][ 0 , italic_T ] into L+1L+1italic_L + 1 timesteps 0=t0<t1<â‹¯<tL=T0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{L}=T0 = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < â‹¯ < italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T, i.e.,

tâ„“=â„“Lâ€‹T,â„“âˆˆ{0,1,â€¦,L}.t_{\ell}=\frac{\ell}{L}T,\qquad\ell\in\{0,1,\dots,L\}.italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG italic_T , roman_â„“ âˆˆ { 0 , 1 , â€¦ , italic_L } . (3.2.34)

Then for each â„“âˆˆ[L]={1,2,â€¦,L}\ell\in[L]=\{1,2,\dots,L\}roman_â„“ âˆˆ [ italic_L ] = { 1 , 2 , â€¦ , italic_L }, going from â„“=L\ell=Lroman_â„“ = italic_L to â„“=1\ell=1roman_â„“ = 1, we can run the iteration

ğ’™^tâ„“âˆ’1\displaystyle\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell-1}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™tâ„“âˆ’1âˆ£ğ’™tâ„“=ğ’™^tâ„“]\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}_{t_{\ell-1}}\mid\bm{x}_{t_{\ell}}=\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}]= blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (3.2.35)
=ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™+tâ„“âˆ’1â€‹ğ’ˆâˆ£ğ’™tâ„“=ğ’™^tâ„“]\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}+t_{\ell-1}\bm{g}\mid\bm{x}_{t_{\ell}}=\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}]= blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_g âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (3.2.36)
=ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™+tâ„“âˆ’1â‹…ğ’™tâ„“âˆ’ğ’™tâ„“âˆ£ğ’™tâ„“=ğ’™^tâ„“]\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\bm{x}+t_{\ell-1}\cdot\frac{\bm{x}_{t_{\ell}}-\bm{x}}{t_{\ell}}\mid\bm{x}_{t_{\ell}}=\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}\right]= blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… divide start_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (3.2.37)
=tâ„“âˆ’1tâ„“â€‹ğ’™^tâ„“+(1âˆ’tâ„“âˆ’1tâ„“)â€‹ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™âˆ£ğ’™tâ„“=ğ’™^tâ„“]\displaystyle=\frac{t_{\ell-1}}{t_{\ell}}\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}+\left(1-\frac{t_{\ell-1}}{t_{\ell}}\right)\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}\mid\bm{x}_{t_{\ell}}=\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}]= divide start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - divide start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (3.2.38)
=(1âˆ’1â„“)â‹…ğ’™^tâ„“+1â„“â‹…ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(tâ„“,ğ’™^tâ„“).\displaystyle=\left(1-\frac{1}{\ell}\right)\cdot\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}+\frac{1}{\ell}\cdot\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t_{\ell},\hat{\bm{x}}_{t_{\ell}}).= ( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG ) â‹… over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG â‹… overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.2.39)

The effect of this iteration is as follows. At the beginning of the iteration where â„“\ellroman_â„“ is large, we barely trust the output of the denoiser, and mostly keep the current iterate. This makes sense, as the denoiser can have huge variance (cf ExampleÂ 3.3). When â„“\ellroman_â„“ is small, the denoiser will â€œlock onâ€ to the modes of the data distribution as a denoising step basically takes a gradient step on the true distributionâ€™s log-density, and we can trust it to not produce unreasonable samples, so the denoising step mostly involves the output of the denoiser. At â„“=1\ell=1roman_â„“ = 1 we even throw away the current iterate and just keep the output of the denoiser.

The above is intuition for why we expect the denoising process to converge. We visualize the convergence process in â„3\mathbb{R}^{3}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in FigureÂ 3.5. We will develop some rigorous results about convergence later. For now, recall that we wanted to build a process to reduce the entropy. While we did do this in a roundabout way by inverting a process which adds entropy, it is now time to pay the piper and confirm that our iterative denoising process reduces the entropy.

Theorem 3.4 (Simplified Version of TheoremÂ B.3).

Suppose that (ğ±t)tâˆˆ[0,T](\bm{x}_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT obeys (3.2.1). Then, under certain technical conditions on ğ±\bm{x}bold_italic_x, for every s<ts<titalic_s < italic_t with s,tâˆˆ(0,T]s,t\in(0,T]italic_s , italic_t âˆˆ ( 0 , italic_T ],

hâ€‹(ğ”¼â¡[ğ’™sâˆ£ğ’™t])<hâ€‹(ğ’™t).h(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}_{s}\mid\bm{x}_{t}])<h(\bm{x}_{t}).italic_h ( blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) < italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.2.40)

The full statement of the theorem, and the proof itself, requires some technicality, so it is postponed to SectionÂ B.2.2.

The last thing we discuss here is that many times, we will not be able to compute ğ’™Â¯âˆ—â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , â‹… ) for any ttitalic_t, since we do not have the distribution ptp_{t}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But we can try to learn one from data. Recall that the denoiser ğ’™Â¯âˆ—\bar{\bm{x}}^{\ast}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is defined in (3.2.3) as minimizing the mean-squared error ğ”¼â¡â€–ğ’™Â¯â€‹(t,ğ’™t)âˆ’ğ’™â€–22\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\|\bar{\bm{x}}(t,\bm{x}_{t})-\bm{x}\|_{2}^{2}blackboard_E âˆ¥ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_italic_x âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We can use this mean-squared error as a loss or objective function to learn the denoiser. For example, we can parameterize ğ’™Â¯â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t , â‹… ) by a neural network, writing it as ğ’™Â¯Î¸â€‹(t,â‹…)\bar{\bm{x}}_{\theta}(t,\cdot)overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , â‹… ), and optimize the loss over the parameter space Î˜\Thetaroman_Î˜:
